authors.name: Wei Xiuren
authors.description: Late Qing novelist known for Huayue Hen, a scholar-and-beauty romance interweaving love with the Taiping Rebellion.

authors.name: Chu Renhuo
authors.description: Early Qing novelist who compiled the Romance of the Sui and Tang Dynasties from earlier historical fiction.

authors.name: Zhang Dai
authors.description: One of the finest prose stylists of late imperial China, known for his nostalgic essays on the vanished world of the late Ming.

authors.name: Li Yu
authors.description: Polymath dramatist, fiction writer, and aesthete who wrote on drama, music, gardening, food, and daily life.

authors.name: Youzhi Daoren
authors.description: Pseudonymous compiler of the Expanded Records of the Forest of Laughter, China's most famous joke collection.

authors.name: Yuan Mei
authors.description: Leading Qing poet and literary critic who championed naturalness and feeling in poetry.

authors.name: Zhong Rong
authors.description: Southern Dynasties literary critic who wrote the earliest systematic ranking of Chinese poets.

authors.name: Wang Fu
authors.description: Eastern Han social critic who wrote trenchant essays on governance, corruption, and moral decay from outside the establishment.

authors.name: Hong Mai
authors.description: Prolific Southern Song scholar and official who compiled one of China's most erudite biji collections.

authors.name: Wang Yinglin
authors.description: Song dynasty scholar known for meticulous evidential scholarship across the classics, histories, and philosophy.

authors.name: Duan Chengshi
authors.description: Tang dynasty polymath whose eclectic biji collection covered natural history, folklore, foreign lands, and supernatural tales.

authors.name: Lu You
authors.description: One of the greatest Song poets, also known for his prose notes on politics, literature, and the Jurchen wars.

authors.name: Meng Yuanlao
authors.description: Southern Song memoirist who recorded the urban life of Northern Song Kaifeng before its fall to the Jurchens.

authors.name: Wang Shizhen
authors.description: Leading poet-critic of the early Qing, known for his theory of 'spiritual resonance' (shengyun) in poetry.

authors.name: Li Daoyuan
authors.description: Northern Wei geographer who transformed a terse river catalog into the greatest geographical text of pre-modern China.

authors.name: Jia Sixie
authors.description: Northern Wei agricultural scholar who compiled the oldest and most comprehensive surviving Chinese agricultural manual.

authors.name: Li Zhi
authors.description: Iconoclastic late Ming thinker who attacked Confucian hypocrisy and championed individual moral autonomy.

texts.title: Traces of Flowers and the Moon (Huayue Hen)
texts.description: A major scholar-and-beauty romance of the late Qing, interweaving love stories with the Taiping Rebellion. Known for its lyrical poetry and depiction of courtesans and failed scholars.

texts.title: Romance of the Sui and Tang Dynasties (Sui Tang Yanyi)
texts.description: The great historical novel of the Sui-Tang transition, covering the fall of the Sui dynasty through the rise of the Tang. Features famous characters like Li Shimin, Qin Shubao, and Cheng Yaojin.

texts.title: Dream Memories of Tao'an (Taoan Mengyi)
texts.description: The finest collection of nostalgic essays in Chinese literature. Zhang Dai, a ruined Ming aristocrat, recalls the vanished world of late Ming Jiangnan: opera, tea, lantern festivals, lake excursions.

texts.title: Random Thoughts on Idle Pleasures (Xianqing Ouji)
texts.description: The most comprehensive manual of aesthetics and daily life in Chinese literature. Covers drama, music, costume, gardening, food, architecture, and health with wit and opinion.

texts.title: Expanded Records of the Forest of Laughter (Xiaolin Guangji)
texts.description: The largest and most famous Chinese joke collection. Hundreds of jokes organized by category: stupid people, ridiculous officials, stingy men, marital humor, and more.

texts.title: Random Notes on Poetry from the Sui Garden (Suiyuan Shihua)
texts.description: The most entertaining collection of poetry criticism in Chinese. Yuan Mei combines anecdotes, critical judgments, and hundreds of quoted poems, championing spirit and feeling over formalism.

texts.title: Grades of Poetry (Shipin)
texts.description: The earliest systematic ranking and critical evaluation of Chinese poets. Zhong Rong grades 122 poets from Han to his own day into three tiers with critical comments on each.

texts.title: Comments of a Recluse (Qianfu Lun)
texts.description: A penetrating social critique of Eastern Han dynasty corruption, nepotism, and moral decay. Wang Fu writes from outside the establishment with sharp observations on governance and human nature.

texts.title: Random Notes from the Rongzhai Studio (Rongzhai Suibi)
texts.description: The most scholarly and wide-ranging biji collection of the Song dynasty. Covers history, literature, philology, politics, and daily life with extraordinary erudition across 1,230 entries.

texts.title: Records of Learning Difficulties (Kunxue Jiwen)
texts.description: One of the greatest works of evidential scholarship in Chinese history. Wang Yinglin meticulously investigates textual problems across the classics, histories, and philosophy.

texts.title: Miscellaneous Morsels from Youyang (Youyang Zazu)
texts.description: The most fascinating and eclectic biji collection of the Tang dynasty. Covers natural history, folklore, foreign lands, Buddhist and Daoist lore, food, drugs, ghosts, and oddities. Contains the earliest known Chinese Cinderella story.

texts.title: Notes from the Old Scholar's Studio (Laoxuean Biji)
texts.description: Personal notes by one of the greatest Song poets. Lu You records anecdotes about politics, literature, customs, and daily life in the Southern Song, full of eyewitness accounts of the Jurchen wars.

texts.title: Dreams of Splendor of the Eastern Capital (Dongjing Menghua Lu)
texts.description: The most detailed account of urban life in the Northern Song capital Kaifeng before its fall to the Jurchen in 1127. Markets, restaurants, festivals, entertainment, and daily customs described with nostalgic precision.

texts.title: Random Talks North of the Pond (Chibei Outan)
texts.description: A major biji collection by the leading poet-critic of the early Qing. Covers literature, history, supernatural tales, and contemporary events across four thematic sections.

texts.title: Commentary on the Waterways Classic (Shuijing Zhu)
texts.description: The greatest geographical text of pre-modern China. Li Daoyuan expanded a terse river catalog into a richly detailed account of landscapes, cities, legends, and inscriptions along China's waterways.

texts.title: Essential Techniques for the Common People (Qimin Yaoshu)
texts.description: The oldest and most comprehensive agricultural manual surviving from China. Covers crop cultivation, animal husbandry, food processing, brewing, and fermentation.

texts.title: A Book to Burn (Fenshu)
texts.description: The most iconoclastic work of the late Ming. Li Zhi attacked Confucian hypocrisy, championed individual moral autonomy, and defended vernacular fiction and women's intellectual capacity.
